content: First, I suggest you identify the accounts for the office365 accounts. Click 'server settings' for each account that uses outlook.office365.com and look at the bottom line that points to local directory. Assuming you have three such accounts, you will see one pointing to the outlook.office365.com, one pointing to outlook.office365.com-1, and another to the -2. That will help you confirm which account is using each. Since you have the prior messages backed up, you can merge them with the current account,and it is a two-step process. You need the importexporttools addon for this. - create local folder for old inbox - highlight and rightclick and select importexport option to import mbox. select and click ok. - now highlight again, rightclick and select importexport option to export as eml. - now, highlight the accounts INBOX, rightclick and select importexport option to import eml. select the emls and click ok - repeat this for sent folder and any other saved folders. - once done, you can delete local folders.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks, David! That worked. In fact, I didn't have to go to the second step. I simply used the importexporttools to import all of the mboxes in the localhost directory, and that restored all of my inbox, sent, junk and trash from the missing Hotmail account going back to 2007.

creator: wsmwk

content:
My main account, the one with the issues, is a POP account. I found out that V 128 or 128.1 had a bug where compacting truncated the file at 4GB, which caused the loss of 5 years of email from my inbox. Fortunately, I have a hierarchy of folders that I move important emails into, so this was more of an annoyance than a tragedy.

As for the duplicates and unreadable messages, a combination of installing V 128.1.1, doing another compacting, rebuilding the folder index, and deleting the Popstate.dat file resolved most of the problems. Thank you to Francesco via Bugzilla.

I do wish that dev team had sent everyone an alert about the serious bug that was found. This saga really shook my confidence in Thunderbird, which I've been using for several decades.

content:
This, at first glance, appears to be rejection for security issues of your email account. The message is sent via Thunderbird, but the receiving server checks authenticity of the host server for the original email, which is your email provider. Problems may be with the SPF and/or DKIM setting. I followed the links you provided and they pointed to fixing it from the sender's account. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/troubleshoot/email-delivery/ndr/fix-error-code-550-4-4-7-in-exchange-online?

Your email provider should recognize the symptoms here. Many email providers are implementing tighter security and it hits users, such as you, without warning. I worked a few days ago with another person whose email situation was similar to yours, in that his were all being rejected by Gmail. The error you are receiving would happen with any email client, but not when using a webmail client.
creator: davidsk

content: My earlier suggestion still stands. The issue's technical components are above my pay grade, but your email provider should be able to address this.

content: Thank You David for looking over my problem and trying to help, then pointing me in another direction to try and get this matter resolved! So far I don't have the problem fixed, but I am still working on it. Have a great day or night whichever it is. NiceSeeingYou aka Keith :)
